Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Micromechanics of Meniscus-bound Particle Clusters

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Surface tension phenomena are important in a variety of physical processes including blending of immiscible fluids, formation of sprays and aerosols and foaming of plastics. This collaborative project concerns particle-liquid mixtures that are generally called particulate suspensions. Examples include slurries encountered in mineral and ceramics processing, particle-filled molten plastics, and printing inks. In such particulate suspensions, the addition of a second immiscible liquid induces particle "sticking" and aggregation due to surface tension and capillary forces. A familiar example is a sandcastle whose strength comes from small water droplets which bind the sand grains together by capillary forces. This project will conduct fundamental studies of interparticle capillary forces in mixing flows. Particle clusters bound by capillary forces will be placed in well-defined flows and studied using new methods in automated flow control. This work aims to understand the flow dynamics of particle clusters and the limits of their stability, which refers to the conditions under which clusters rupture due to the applied flow. Over the past decade, surface tension-induced particle clustering has been exploited for a wide range materials and materials-processing applications including macroporous ceramics, 3D printing, conductive plastics, and printing electronic circuits. The results of this project will enable rational design of mixing operations that exploit capillary forces to develop new materials.

In multiphase suspensions containing particles and two immiscible liquids, capillary forces can induce particle clustering. The clusters comprise two or more particles bound by a meniscus liquid. In this project, the dynamics and rupture mechanics of particle clusters in simple shear or planar extensional flow fields will be studied using video microscopy and automated flow control. A feedback-controlled microfluidic device known as a Stokes trap will be used to precisely manipulate particles using viscous forces, to create well-defined meniscus-bound particle clusters, and to subject the clusters to precisely controlled flows. This work aims to achieve a fundamental understanding of the dynamics and rupture of particle clusters in well-defined flows. The project will reveal fundamentally new information, including the criteria for rupture of particle clusters, and how these criteria depend on the composition of the cluster, viscosity of the meniscus fluid, and particle roughness. Thedesign of mixing operations for liquid/liquid/particle mixtures is presently empirical in nature. This project will establish micromechanics-based design rules for such mixing operations that exploit capillary forces to develop new materials. The project will form the basis for training of graduate and undergraduate students. The two principal investigators will conduct numerous outreach activities at the undergraduate and pre-college level, including recruitment of underrepresented groups into their research groups, and mentorship of high-school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on understanding the dynamics of particle clusters bound by capillary forces in flow environments. Particle clusters and particulate suspensions are ubiquitous in everyday life and are composed of two immiscible liquids (a wetting phase and a suspending phase) and solid particles. Capillary suspensions play a key role in commercial applications such as foods and personal care products. By investigating how these particle clusters behave under different flow conditions, this project provided a significant advance in understanding how to design improved processes and manufacturing methods for new functional materials.

The overarching goal of the project was to study the dynamics of particle clusters in flow using cutting-edge techniques in flow-based manipulation and analysis of microscale particles. This research addressed several key scientific questions about the breakup and rearrangement of these clusters in flow, such as the conditions under which they rupture, and how different flow types affect cluster stability. To achieve these goals, the project was divided into two major project areas or directions. In one area, the dynamics of meniscus-bound particle clusters was studied in extensional flow. Here, an automated flow control system known as the Stokes trap was used to manipulate and study freely suspended particles to observe how clusters deform and break up under flow. The Stokes trap allows for precise control and long-term observation of clusters, which is crucial for understanding how they behave under various flow conditions. In a second area, the dynamics of meniscus-bound particle clusters in shear flow was studied using a custom-built shear flow device compatible with optical and fluorescence microscopy. In this way, the dynamics of particulate clusters was studied in precisely controlled shear flow. 

The project made significant strides in understanding the dynamics of capillary suspensions, with several key accomplishments in particle cluster dynamics in different flow fields. Published work from this project included detailed experimental and theoretical work on two-particle clusters (doublets) in extensional flow. This work included the development of new analytical models that accurately describe the non-equilibrium dynamics of particle clusters in flow, including capillary forces, hydrodynamic forces, and interparticle hydrodynamic interactions. These models were in good agreement with experimental data, helping to explain the underlying micromechanics of these materials. This work revealed the role of interparticle hydrodynamic interactions on governing the conformational dynamics and breakup phenomena of particle clusters in flow. In addition, a significant breakthrough included the development of a 3D Stokes trap, which is the first method allowing for manipulation of small particles in three-dimensional space using only fluid flow. This system allows for the observation of particle deformation and relaxation under controlled flow conditions. Moreover, this research also included understanding the dynamics of multi-particle clusters in shear flow. This work used machine learning (ML) and computer vision techniques to analyze video data from experiments, offering new insights into the behavior of larger particle clusters.

Overall, this research holds promise to enhance our understanding of a wide range of particulate and colloidal systems for a variety of materials applications. By providing a fundamental understanding of how particle clusters behave in flow, the project can help to inform the design of new flow-based processes for material synthesis. This work will aid in the development of new materials with tailored microstructures and mechanical properties, such as improved strength or flexibility. The project’s findings could also influence the design of enhanced mixing processes in industries ranging from pharmaceuticals to construction materials, where the control of particle suspensions is critical. The use of advanced analytical techniques such as the Stokes trap and machine learning methods to understand particle behavior represents a leap forward in our ability to control and design new materials on a microscopic scale. Overall, this project has provided valuable new insights into the behavior of capillary-bound particle clusters, laying the groundwork for future innovations in material design and processing. With continued research and refinement, these findings may lead to more efficient and precise manufacturing techniques for a wide range of industries.
